import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 
data = pd.read_csv("../input/habermans-survival-data-set/haberman.csv")
data.columns = ["age", "year", "nodes", "status"]
data
source.976c4811: data.shape # data has 306 observations and 4 variables
source.1d6486a0:
# Creating new dataframes with records with status= 1 and status= 2
status1 = data.loc[data["status"] == 1]
status2 = data.loc[data["status"] == 2]
source.469f326b:
plt.plot(status1["age"],np.zeros_like(status1["age"]), '+',label='survived')
plt.plot(status2["age"], np.zeros_like(status2["age"]), 'o',label='not survived')
plt.title("1 d scatter plot of age ")
plt.xlabel("age")
plt.legend()

plt.show()
source.ba491e90:
plt.plot(status1["nodes"],np.zeros_like(status1["nodes"]), '+',label='survived')
plt.plot(status2["nodes"], np.zeros_like(status2["nodes"]), 'o',label=' not survived')
plt.xlabel("no of lymph nodes")
plt.legend();
plt.title("1 d scatter plot of nodes ")
plt.show()
source.d4a41ebc:
plt.plot(status1["year"],np.zeros_like(status1["year"]), '+',label='survived')
plt.plot(status2["year"], np.zeros_like(status2["year"]), '-',label=' not survived')
plt.xlabel("year of operation")
plt.legend();
plt.title("1 d scatter plot of year of surgery ")
plt.show()
source.59917b19:
sns.FacetGrid(data, hue="status", size=5) \
   .map(sns.distplot, "age") \
   .add_legend()
plt.title("PDF curves and Histogram for age ")
plt.show();
source.18f843f4:
counts, bin_edges = np.histogram(status1['age'], bins=10, 
                                 density = True)
pdf = counts/(sum(counts))

cdf = np.cumsum(pdf)
plt.plot(bin_edges[1:],pdf,color="green", label="PDF,status1")
plt.plot(bin_edges[1:], cdf,color="green" ,label="CDF,status2")



counts, bin_edges = np.histogram(status2['age'], bins=10, 
                                 density = True)
pdf = counts/(sum(counts))

cdf = np.cumsum(pdf)
plt.plot(bin_edges[1:],pdf,color="red",label="PDF,status2")
plt.plot(bin_edges[1:], cdf,color="red",label="CDF,status2")


plt.xlabel("age")
plt.ylabel("probability")
plt.legend()
plt.title("PDF and CDf  curves of ages camparison ")
plt.show();
source.19be19de:
counts, bin_edges = np.histogram(status1['year'], bins=10, 
                                 density = True)
pdf = counts/(sum(counts))
print(pdf);
print(bin_edges)
cdf = np.cumsum(pdf)
plt.plot(bin_edges[1:],pdf,color="green", label="PDF,status1")
plt.plot(bin_edges[1:], cdf,color="green" ,label="CDF,status1")



counts, bin_edges = np.histogram(status2['year'], bins=10, 
                                 density = True)
pdf = counts/(sum(counts))
print(pdf);
print(bin_edges)
cdf = np.cumsum(pdf)
plt.plot(bin_edges[1:],pdf,color="red",label="pdf,status2")
plt.plot(bin_edges[1:],cdf,color="red", label="cdf,status2")

plt.title("CDF and PDF of year of surgery ")

plt.legend()

plt.show();
source.0dcc27c7:
counts, bin_edges = np.histogram(status1['nodes'], bins=5, 
                                 density = True)
pdf = counts/(sum(counts))
print(pdf);
print(bin_edges)
cdf = np.cumsum(pdf)
plt.plot(bin_edges[1:],pdf,color="green", label="PDF,status1")
plt.plot(bin_edges[1:], cdf,color="green" ,label="CDF,status1")



counts, bin_edges = np.histogram(status2['nodes'], bins=5, 
                                 density = True)
pdf = counts/(sum(counts))
print(pdf);
print(bin_edges)
cdf = np.cumsum(pdf)
plt.plot(bin_edges[1:],pdf,color="red",label="PDF,status2")
plt.plot(bin_edges[1:], cdf,color="red",label="CDF,status2")

plt.title("CDF and PDF no of nodes camparison ")
plt.xlabel("nodes")
plt.ylabel("probability")
plt.legend()
xmin, xmax = plt.xlim(0,50)
ymin, ymax = plt.ylim(0.0,1.0)
plt.show();

source.ed51cefa:
# Observation:    



1. The Patients survived- 225 , then the one who died -81 after 5 years of surgery .
2.	The average value of age for the patients who survived after the surgery is 52.01
3.	The average no of nodes for the paients who survived after the surgery is 2.79
3.	75% of people who survived have age less then 60 years of age.
5.	50% of people who survived have nodes = 0.
6.	No one above age of 77 survived.
7.	No one with node count above 46 survived.
8.	The average no of nodes in person who could not survive was 7.4.
9. 75% of people above node count 1 could not survive.
10.	Patients with age less then 33 have 100% survived.
11.	Patients with age greater then 80 could not survive.
12. Lymph nodes greater then 50 could not survive.
13.	with increase in node count the no of survivals is always less then the non survivals becomes 0 above 50 value.
14.	people with year of surgery around 60's have higher survival chances then people with surgery,s around 65.
15.	It can be observed from the above graph that the people with ages lower than 38 usually survive after the brest cancer surgery and from 38 to 42 they relatively higher chances of survival.
16. During 1962-1965 the chances of survival were 50 percent approx.
17.	People with less then 10 no of nodes have more then 90% changes of survival.
18.	Age group 30-34 have 100% survival rate.
19.	Age group 78 and above could not survive for five years after the surgery.
20. 50 percentile of people surviving have node value equal to 0.
21.	People with age between 30 and 40 operated in 1958,1960,1961,1962,1963,1964,1965,1967,1969 have survived .

source.f2bf1283:
# Objective

To perform exploratory data analysis to determine whether a patient will survive for 5 year or longer based on the attributes.
source.b4244649:
The various attributes of the data set are:

1.Age of patient at the time of operation(numerical)

2.Patient’s year of operation (year between 1958 to 1970, numerical)

3.Number of positive axillary nodes detected (numerical)

4.Survival status (class attribute) denoted as:

  

*   1 — if the patient survived 5 years or longer


*   2 — if the patient died within 5 years

source.0bc3c926:
# EXPLORATORY DATA ANALYSIS ON HABERMAN'S CANCER SURVIVAL DATA SET

## Haberman’s Survival Data set .
The dataset contains cases from a study that was conducted between 1958 and 1970 at the University of Chicago’s Billings Hospital on the survival of patients who had undergone surgery for breast cancer.
